## Introduction (cont.)
- Viruses cause a wide range of diseases in humans, animals, and plants
- Many virus: responsible for subclinical or mild infections (e.g, *Adenovirus*, *Rhinovirus*)
- Other viruses: cause severe diseases (e.g., *HIV*, *Ebola*, *SARS-CoV-2*)

## Definition of virus
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="70%"}
- Intracellular parasites  
- Contain **either DNA or RNA** [(never both)]{.red-text} 
- Unable to reproduce independently — require a host cell  
- Too small to be seen under a light microscope range from **20-300 nm**
:::

![](images/1200px-Ebola_virus_em.jpg){width="50%" style="border-radius:10px;"}

:::

## General structure of viruses

- **Core (Genome)** — genetic material
- **Capsid** — protein coat surrounding the genome
- **Envelope (optional)** — lipid membrane derived from host

![](images/gen_str.jpg){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}


## Genome

- Made of **DNA or RNA**
- May be **single-stranded (ss)** or **double-stranded (ds)**  
- Can be **linear, circular, or segmented**

![](images/virus_genome.png){width="70%" fig-align="center"}


## Capsomer & Capsid {.smaller}
::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
**Capsomer**

- Made of one or more **polypeptides**  
- Combine to form the **capsid**

**Capsid**

- Protein coat made of capsomers
- Protects the viral genome
- Determines **shape and symmetry** of the virus

**Nucleocapsid**

- Combination of **capsid + genome**
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

![](images/virus_str1.png){width="80%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:100px; border-radius:10px;"}

![](images/virus_str.png){width="80%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}
:::
::::

## Envelope
::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="75%"}
- **Lipid membrane** derived from host cell -> "hide from immune system" 
- Contains viral glycoproteins (e.g., hemagglutinin, neuraminidase) for attachment and entry 
- Not all viruses have envelopes

- **Enveloped**: e.g., *Influenza virus*, *HIV*, *Herpes simplex virus (HSV)*
- **Non-enveloped or Naked**: e.g., *Adenovirus*, *Poliovirus*
:::

::: {.column width="25%"}
![](images/image11.png){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}
:::
::::

## Consequences of envelope{.font14}
**Envelop**

- **Sensitive to heat, acid, and detergents**  
- **Spread by direct contact or droplets (HSV, HIV)**  
- Easily inactivated outside host  

**Non-enveloped or naked**

- More resistant and stable (e.g., drying, detergents, acid) 
- Transmission through fomites (contaminated surfaces) via fecal-oral route 
- Can survive longer outside the host. E.g., *Adenovirus*, *Poliovirus*

![](images/detergent.jpg){.absolute right="10" top="25" width="150" height="auto"}

![](images/detergent_virus.jpg){.absolute top="260" right="20" width="100" height="auto"}

## E.g Enveloped vs Non-Enveloped Viruses (cont.)

| **Enveloped viruses**  | **Non-Enveloped viruses**  |
|------------------------|----------------------------|
| *Herpesviridae*        | *Adenoviridae*             |
| *Retroviridae*         | *Picornaviridae*           |
| *Coronaviridae*        | *Parvoviridae*             |
| *Orthomyxoviridae*     | *Caliciviridae*            |


## Symmetry of Capsid

- **Helical** – rod-like spiral  
- **Icosahedral** – spherical, 20 faces  
- **Complex** – irregular (e.g., bacteriophages)

![](images/morpho_virus.png){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}

## Helical symmetry

- Genome coiled within capsid proteins  
- Found in RNA viruses like **Influenza** or **Tobacco mosaic virus**

![](images/tabacco_mosaic_virus.png)

## Icosahedral symmetry

- Efficient, stable, and common in many animal viruses  
- Example: *Adenovirus*, *Poliovirus*

![](images/adenovirus.jpg){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}

[Click to find 3D models in Sketchfab](https://sketchfab.com/search?q=virus&type=models){target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" style="font-size:16px; color:blue;"}

## Complex symmetry

- Not purely helical or icosahedral  
- Seen in large viruses like **_Poxvirus_** and **Bacteriophage**

![](images/phage.jpg){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}

## Shape & size

- Spherical, rod-shaped, bullet-shaped, or complex  
![](images/shapeandsize.jpg){width="60%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}

## Baltimore classification

- **Type of nucleic acid** (DNA or RNA)  
- **Strandedness** (single or double)  
- **Mode of replication**

![](images/baltimore.png){width="100%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}

## Baltimore classification (cont.){.smaller}
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
| Group | Type |Mnemonic |
|-------|------|---------|
| I | dsDNA | HAPPY* |
| II | ssDNA | *Parvovirus* |
| III | dsRNA | *Rotavirus* |
| IV | (+) ssRNA | +RNA* |
| V | (–) ssRNA | *Influenza* |
| VI | ssRNA-RT | *HIV* |
| VII | dsDNA-RT | *Hepatitis B* |

- **dsDNA: HAPPY** (Herpes, Adeno, Papova, Pox, Y)
- **+RNA(TOGA party I drink FLAVored CORONA and eat small PICORNA CALI soup.)** (Toga, Flavi, Corona, Picorna, Calici)

:::

![](images/image15.jpeg){width="70%" style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-radius:10px;"}
:::

## Other classification
- Since 1975, the **International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV)** has developed a universal virus classification system:
  - Order (-virales)  e.g. *Herpesvirales*
  - Family (-viridae)  e.g. *Herpesviridae*
  - Subfamily (-virinae)  e.g. *Alphaherpesvirinae*
  - Genus (-virus)  e.g. *Simplexvirus*
  - Species (common name)  e.g. *Human herpesvirus 1*

## Writing virus names{.smaller}

| Level           | Example           | Ending / Style    | Writing Style                                            |
| --------------- | ----------------- | ----------------- | -------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Order**       | *Amarillovirales* | –virales          | *Italicized, Capitalize first letter*                    |
| **Family**      | *Flaviviridae*    | –viridae          | *Italicized, Capitalize first letter*                    |
| **Genus**       | *Flavivirus*      | –virus            | *Italicized, Capitalize first letter*                    |
| **Species**     | *Dengue virus*    | (no fixed ending) | *Italicized, Capitalize first letter only of first word* |
| **Common name** | dengue virus      | (descriptive)     | *Not italicized; lowercase*                              |


# Quiz

## Which of the following best defines a virus?{.quiz-question}

A) A living organism that can reproduce independently  
B) [An intracellular parasite containing either DNA or RNA that requires a host cell to reproduce]{.correct}
C) A type of bacteria that causes disease  
D) A protein structure that can self-replicate  


## What are the three main types of capsid symmetry found in viruses?{.quiz-question}

A) Circular, linear, and segmented  
B) Small, medium, and large  
C) [Helical, icosahedral, and complex]{.correct}  
D) DNA, RNA, and protein  

## Which statement about enveloped viruses is CORRECT?{.quiz-question}

A) They are more stable in the environment than non-enveloped viruses  
B) [They are sensitive to heat, acid, and detergents]{.correct}  
C) They can only infect bacterial cells  
D) They always contain DNA genomes  


## In the Baltimore Classification System, Group IV viruses are characterized by:{.quiz-question}

A) Double-stranded DNA  
B) Single-stranded DNA  
C) [Positive-sense single-stranded RNA (+ssRNA)]{.correct}  
D) Double-stranded RNA  

## Who discovered the first virus (Tobacco mosaic virus) and in what year?{.quiz-question}

A) Louis Pasteur in 1885  
B) [Dimitri Ivanovsky in 1892]{.correct}  
C) Frederick Towrt in 1915  
D) Felix d'Herrelle in 1917  

## Which virus family does HIV belong to, and what type of genetic material does it contain?{.quiz-question}

A) Herpesviridae; DNA  
B) [Retroviridae; RNA]{.correct}  
C) Adenoviridae; DNA  
D) Picornaviridae; RNA  

## What is the characteristic feature of _Coronaviridae_ family viruses?{.quiz-question}

A) Icosahedral capsid without envelope  
B) [Crown-like spike proteins on envelope surface]{.correct}  
C) Complex symmetry with tail fibers  
D) Helical nucleocapsid without envelope  

## According to Baltimore Classification, which group does Hepatitis B virus belong to?{.quiz-question}

A) Group I (dsDNA)  
B) Group VI (ssRNA-RT)  
C) [Group VII (dsDNA-RT)]{.correct}  
D) Group IV (+ssRNA)  

## Which of the following viruses is NON-ENVELOPED?{.quiz-question}

A) Influenza virus  
B) Herpes simplex virus  
C) [Rotavirus]{.correct}  
D) SARS-CoV-2  

## What makes _Parvovirus_ unique among DNA viruses?{.quiz-question}

A) It has the largest genome  
B) [It contains single-stranded DNA]{.correct}  
C) It only infects bacteria  
D) It has complex symmetry  

## Classify viruses. Which are the main classification criteria?{.quiz-question}

A) Size and color only  
B) [Type of nucleic acid, capsid symmetry, and presence/absence of envelope]{.correct}  
C) Host species and transmission route only  
D) Geographic location and discovery date
